title: 106_hr583
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" and addresses the treatment of Assistant United States Attorneys. The Act, known as the "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998," includes amendments to the Civil Service Retirement System and the Federal Employees' Retirement System regarding the definition of a law enforcement officer to now include Assistant United States Attorneys. The "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" amends the Civil Service Retirement System and the Federal Employees' Retirement System to include Assistant United States Attorneys as law enforcement officers. This is defined in the Act by adding Assistant United States Attorneys to the list of law enforcement officers. The "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" defines an Assistant United States Attorney as an assistant appointed under section 542 of title 28. The Act and its amendments will take effect on the first day of the first pay period after 90 days from enactment. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO INCUMBENTS. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO INCUMBENTS. 
For purposes of this section, an incumbent is an individual first appointed as an Assistant United States Attorney before the effective date of this Act. The Department of Justice must provide notice to incumbents regarding their election rights under this Act within 6 months of its effective date. Incumbents may choose to be treated according to the amendments made by this Act or as if the Act had never been enacted. Failure to make a timely election will have consequences. An incumbent may choose to be treated according to the amendments made by the Act or as if the Act had never been enacted. The election must be made before the 90th day after receiving notice or separation from service. No change in retirement coverage for incumbents. An incumbent must make an election before the 90th day after receiving notice or separation from service. No change in retirement coverage for incumbents until the election is made. Retroactive effect for those who elect the option under subsection (c)(1)(A). The option under subsection (c)(1)(A) allows incumbents to elect retroactive effect for service as an Assistant United States Attorney. Makeup contributions may be required in addition to other payments under title 5, United States Code. Makeup contributions may be required by the Department of Justice under subchapter III of chapter 83 or chapter 84 of title 5, United States Code. The remitted amount will be deposited in the Treasury to the credit of the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. The remitted amount, including additional individual and Government contributions to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund, will be deposited in the Treasury. This amount is based on contributions that would have been required before the effective date of the election, plus interest. No individual liability is imposed by this Act or the relevant chapters of title 5, United States Code. The Act requires additional contributions to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund by Assistant United States Attorneys before their election, with no individual liability imposed. The Office of Personnel Management will establish regulations for implementation, including determining interest on the required contributions. The Office of Personnel Management will create regulations for the Act, including determining interest on required contributions by Assistant United States Attorneys. The term "Assistant United States Attorney" is defined as an assistant appointed under section 542 of title 28, United States Code.
